title: Le dit de Guillaume d’Engleterre
summary: An alexandrine reworking of the epic tale of Guillaume d’Angleterre.

title: Le dit des trois mors et III vis
summary: A discussion between three living and three dead men on the importance of living a good life.

title: Un dist que on clamme respon
summary: A girl is saved from rape, and a canon from death, by their devotion to Mary.

title: La chace des mesdisans (copy A)
summary: The hunt for an allegorical boar, representing a ‘mesdisant’. One of two copies in the manuscript.

title: La lande dorée
summary: The author‑narrator tells of discovering a beautiful lady in a forest idyll, who agrees to be his lover if he completes a certain task. The text ends here.

title: La repentance Rutebeuf
summary: Rutebeuf, apparently close to death, expresses regret for his life choices.

title: La desputoisson du vin et de l’iaue
summary: A debate in which wines of different types plead their case before the God of Love, before water wins the day.

title: Le pas Salhadin
summary: A narrative poem describing key events from the Third Crusade.

title: L’erberie
summary: A herb seller sells his saucy wares.

title: Le dit de Charlot et du barbier
summary: A debate between a Christian and a Jew.

title: Le dit des trois chanoinnes
summary: Three canons choose a life of penitence and help a sinning knight achieve redemption.

title: Le lai de l’oiselet
summary: An anti‑vilain tale in which a rural idyll is ruined by a peasant’s wicked ways.

title: La complainte Rutebeuf
summary: Rutebeuf laments his lot.

title: Le dit des traverces
summary: Nonsense poetry in the first person, with reference to locations and religious figures.

title: Le Paternostre du vin
summary: A fragmentary text of which only the final 24 lines survive. Likely a Goliardic parody on the words of the Pater Noster, with stanzas introduced by words of the Latin.

title: Le chapel des VII flors
summary: A lyric poem in which advice on seven feminine virtues is given through the allegory of flowers.

title: Boivin de Provins
summary: The manuscript’s only fabliau, about a jongleur who gets one over on a group of unscrupulous prostitutes.

title: Ave Maria
summary: The words of the Latin Ave Maria each taken to create a stanza in praise of Mary.

title: Le dit des III pommes
summary: Two friends, united by a pilgrimage miracle, both sacrifice something for the other.

title: Li livres des secrés Aristote
summary: Pseudo‑Aristotelian prose purporting to contain advice from Aristotle to Alexander on how to be a good king. A translation of the Secreta Secretorum.

title: Le dit des planetes (copy A)
summary: An estates satire comparing seven types of people with the seven planets and seven days of the week. One of two copies in the manuscript.

title: Le dit de l’espervier
summary: Invective against inconstant, avaricious women.

title: La grant bible Nostre Dame
summary: Praise of the Virgin Mary interspersed with anti‑semitic invective.

title: Les VII dormant
summary: A prose list of ‘the seven sleepers.’

title: La vision de saint Paul
summary: A vernacular, alexandrine version of the visio sancti Pauli.

title: Les XXX jorz perilleus de l’an
summary: A prose list of the 30 days of the year that represent the most peril.

title: Le dit de la bourjoise de Romme
summary: A pious woman is tempted to incest and kills her child, but is saved by Mary.

title: La vie du monde
summary: Rutebeuf offers satirical criticism of the three estates.

title: Le dit des II chevaliers
summary: A tale about the fates of two knights, one who is pious and one who is not.

title: Le dit de l’enfant rosti
summary: The Devil roasts the child of a pious couple, but Jesus is on hand to save the day.

title: Le dit du povre chevalier
summary: Mary takes the place of a woman to save her and her husband from the Devil.

title: Du chevalier et de l’escuier
summary: A knight and his squire suffer for denying their faith in return for earthly reward.

title: Le dit de la borjoise de Narbonne
summary: A widow saves her son from execution by appealing to Mary.

title: Le dit du chevalier qui devint hermite
summary: A sinful knight undergoes trials to redeem his soul before becoming a hermit.

title: Le dit du cordouanier
summary: The Devil leads a cordwainer to kill his wife, but Mary revives her and he is saved.

title: Le dit du petit Juitel
summary: A Jewish child converts to Christianity.

title: Le dit de l’enfant qui sauva sa mere
summary: A child saves his mother from damnation by performing her penance after her death.

title: Le dit de l’eaue beneoite et du vergier
summary: A bipartite tale in which a convert discovers the true power of holy water, and then a greedy man is turned from wickedness by a dream.

title: Le dit du riche home qui geta le pain a la teste du povre
summary: An avaricious man throws bread at a peasant’s head and realises the error of his ways.

title: Le dit du chien et du mescreant
summary: A non‑believer tries to feed the Host to his dog, which devours him instead.

title: Le dit de la pecherresse qui estrangla III enfans
summary: Mary saves a pious woman who is tempted into incest and kills her children.

title: Le dit de la rebellion d’Engleterre et de Flandres
summary: Anti‑English invective written as advice for a king.

title: Le dit des mais
summary: A poem explaining how all roles in society are important, but greed so often gets the better of us all.

title: Le martyre de saint Bacchus
summary: A parodic hagiography of Saint Bacchus (that is, wine).

title: La requeste des freres meneurs sus le septiesme Climent le quint
summary: Satirical criticism of monastic orders, addressed to Pope Clement V.

title: Le dit des patenostres
summary: Discussion of, and prayers for, all the estates.

title: Le dit de Nostre Dame
summary: Three separate poems, all in praise of the Virgin Mary.

title: La panthere d’amors
summary: A dream allegory on bestiary themes, in which the narrator learns the significance of the panther and other beasts, as well as flowers and stones.

title: Isopet
summary: A version of the Ysopet (Paris II) containing 40 different tales.

title: Dit du tournoiement d’Antecrist et d’euls de son barnage
summary: An allegorical tourney between the forces of the Light and the Dark.

title: Lai d’amour 1
summary: An untitled lai d’amour, of which the end is missing.

title: Le dit de Merlin Mellot
summary: A peasant receives riches from Merlin but loses them through his lack of respect.

title: Le dit de Robert le Diable
summary: An alexandrine reworking of the epic tale of Robert the Devil.

title: De Florence de Romme
summary: An alexandrine reworking of the epic tale of Florence of Rome.

title: Le dit de menage
summary: A debate in which three speakers discuss the merits and disadvantages of married life.
edition_title: Le Dit de Menage: A Fourteenth-Century Set of Anti-Matrimonial, Anti-Clerical, Anti-English Dialogues

title: Le dit des anelés
summary: A wife cheats on her husband while on pilgrimage but is eventually redeemed.

title: Yonec
summary: One of Marie de France’s lais, in which a bird‑knight’s tragic death at the hands of his lover’s jealous husband is eventually avenged by his son.

title: Les divisions de LXXII biautés qui sont en dames
summary: A verse list of the 72 beauties to be found in women, most of which are physical.

title: Li dis des trois mortes et des trois vives
summary: A fragmentary discussion between three living and three dead women on the importance of living a good life, of which only 12 lines survive.

title: Le dit du buef
summary: Three sinners, united through incest, are saved by penance.

title: Le dit des rues de Paris
summary: A guided tour of the streets of Paris.

title: Le dit du Lendit rimé
summary: Praise of merchants, in particular those of the Lendit market.

title: Le dit des planetes (copy B)
summary: An estates satire comparing seven types of people with the seven planets and seven days of the week. One of two copies in the manuscript.

title: Le dit de l’arbre d’amours et de touz ses [fruits] bons et mauvais
summary: An allegory in which the narrator tastes the sweet and bitter fruits of the tree of love.

title: Le dit du chastoi du jone gentil homme
summary: An exhortation for young men to eschew sin and choose the path of righteousness.

title: Le dit des II loiaus compaignons
summary: A tale about two imprisoned men who are freed as a result of their loyal bond.

title: Le dit du vilain despensier
summary: A warning against being too charitable towards the poor.

title: Li livres des songes Daniel et les songes Macrobe
summary: Prose discussion of the meaning of dreams.

title: Serventois a Valenchiennes
summary: A series of short songs, often on themes of love and devotion.

title: Lai d’amour 2
summary: Another untitled love poem.

title: Le dit de la beguine
summary: A rich beguine is damned for a deal she makes with the Devil involving the Host.

title: Le dit de l'enfant qui mist l’anel que s’amie li avoit donné ou doit a l’ymage de Nostre Dame
summary: Part of Gautier de Coincy’s Miracles de Nostre Dame, in which a young clerc promises himself to Mary but then forgets her, before being reminded of his promise.

title: Le dit du hardi cheval
summary: A parodic attempt to sell an unsaleable horse.

title: Le tretié sus la messe qui est dit mirouer d’iglusse que frere Hue de l’ordre des Prescheurs ordena
summary: An anonymous prose translation of Hugues de Saint‑Cher’s Speculum ecclesiae.

title: Lucidaires
summary: A translation of the Latin Elucidarium, featuring a prose debate between a master and his student on matters of faith. An extension to the original text begins on f. 361ra.

title: Le dit du preu chevalier
summary: An allegorical tale in which a knight visits all the virtues until he reaches prowess.

title: Le dit de l’iraygne
summary: A dream allegory in which the narrator observes a spider fighting a toad, with Reason on hand to explain the meaning.

title: Le dit des drois
summary: A collection of proverbs and sayings explaining good behaviour.

title: Le dit du roy
summary: Advice addressed to the King of the French, summarising the virtues that Aristotle explained to Alexander.

title: Le dit de la nois
summary: An encomium to nuts, which are said to represent all positive virtues.

title: La prise amoureuse de jonesce
summary: An allegory in which the narrator is the object of a hunt by Love and his entourage.

title: Le dit de la chace des mesdissans (copy B)
summary: The hunt for an allegorical boar, representing a ‘mesdisant’. One of two copies in the manuscript.

title: Le dit de dame Jouenne
summary: A comic dialogue in which Jouenne’s husband punishes her for her shrewishness.

title: Le miroir de vie et de mort
summary: A dream allegory in which the Seven Deadly Sins discuss their power over mankind.

title: Les proverbes de Salomon
summary: Prose presentation, with commentary, of the words of a number of saints and prophets. There are indications of an attempted presentation as dialogue.

title: La misere de l’omme
summary: An anonymous prose translation of De misera humanae conditionis by Latin by Cardinal Lotario dei Segni, the future Pope Innocent III.
